It's not the same as human intelligence due to the fact that humans haven't evolved to use a specific tool (like a saw) but still can use it flawlessly after some time. Actually the statement about trying to hit a beer bottle with a snowball at fifty feet away would be the same as what the archer fish does is not exactly accurate (pardon the pun). The reason it can do what it does is because it is so small. If some how we could increase the size of the archer fish to that of a human, it would no longer be able to spit as far in comparison to its body for at least two reasons. The first is that as something gets bigger its mass increases far more. Thus to spit a volume of water equivalent to what it spits at its normal size it would need far more strength then its muscles could possibly generate. The second reason is that water does not behave the same as it does at its normal size. It turns into droplets.

oh, this isn't even getting into some cool stuff. water bends light- in order for the fish to accurately aim, it has to take that light bend into account. the fish isn't even shooting at where its target appears to be, it's shooting at where it has calculated it to be!

archerfish also face some competition from other archerfish. when they knock a bug into the water, other archerfish occasionally make a grab for it. some fish have combated this using even MORE math! they'll shoot and immediately move to where the bug is, before it even hits the water. they're calculating where a bug they can't accurately see will fall, and moving to intercept it! smart fish, indeed!

When I think of "tool use", I imagine an animal living in a forest and looking for specifically shaped sticks and stones for a specific task. In this task, the animal is envisioning itself using the tool when discriminating between tool-candidates.
The archer fish will always have water around it and any gulp of water is good enough. That's not tool use in my book.

"If you don't have our [human] hardware, you can't do what we can do." - I don't think anyone actually says that, especially not those who study intelligence. A computer does not have a neocortex either, and yet they can detect faces better than humans (faster and more accurately). The idea that the Archerfish is using tools here is dubious as well. With such an expanded definition, birds (another type of animal without a neocortex) use air as a tool to fly, making complex calculations about air pressure, wind resistance, and so forth.
